newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds open softer but mood remains up.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds open softer but mood remains up.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened softer on Wednesday, easing after yesterday's rally and volatile ahead of a C$1.3 billion auction of 30-year bonds, analysts said.

The Bank of Canada will auction 8.0 percent bonds due June 1, 2027 at 1315 EDT/1715 GMT and investors are unlikely to buy new supply with prices near all-time highs, said Sheldon Dong, Midland Walwyn Capital's manager of fixed-income research. "It creates a lot of uncertainty in our bond market."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond slipped C$0.16 to C$120.34 to yield 6.454 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond rose 1/32 to yield 6.41 percent. The spread between the two stayed steady at four basis points from Tuesday's close.

Hank Cunningham, director of fixed income at First Marathon Securities, added that Canadian bond markets were also taking a breather after yesterday's rally on bullish comments by U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. "Some sober reflection on what Greenspan had to say gave pause," Cunningham said.
Greenspan, who signalled that U.S. short-term interest rates were likely to remain steady for the time being, will finish his Congress testimony today.

Some market players were worried about a short-term pull-back, but both analysts said that Canada's market would power higher as rate hikes were kept at bay. "The mood is pretty bullish," Cunningham said.

In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond lost C$0.26 to reach C$109.86 to yield 5.913 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond lost 1/32 to yield 6.13 percent, so the negative spread between the bonds narrowed to 22 basis points from Tuesday's close.
